intro: Lupsia lehmannii, commonly known as Lehmann's lupine, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its distinctive pea-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought conditions. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several small leaflets, and it produces pods that contain seeds. Lupsia lehmannii plays a role in nitrogen fixation, contributing to soil fertility in its native habitat.
